Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Modular Vertex Operator Algebras Associated with the Virasoro Algebra
Award.AbstractNarration:
The theory of vertex operator algebras is a mathematical framework whose importance reaches well outside of mathematics. It is prevalent in theoretical physics, in particular, conformal field theory and string theory, which attempt to provide a unified description of all the forces of nature. While a vertex operator algebra is most often considered over the field of complex numbers or fields of characteristic zero, little is known about those over a field of prime characteristic p. A better understanding of vertex operator algebras over fields of prime characteristic plays an important role in the study of modular representations of finite groups, rational vertex operator algebras, and rational conformal field theory. This project will be conducted at the Graduate School of Information Science and Technology at Osaka University under the mentorship of Prof. Kiyokazu Nagatomo, who specializes in the theory of vertex operator algebras which correspond to conformal field theory in physics.

In vertex operator algebra theory, rationality is considered to be among the most important concepts. The primary interest of this project is to investigate the rationality of modular vertex operator algebras associated with the minimal series of the Virasoro algebra. The goal is to extend some existing results from the fields of characteristic zero to fields whose characteristic satisfies a certain conjectured relation. The plan is to investigate the singular vectors of the Verma modules over such fields.

This NSF EAPSI award provides an international research opportunity to a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supported by an NSF 2017 EAPSI Fellowship, the PI completed her research project on Modular Vertex Operator Algebras Associated with the Virasoro Algebra. Such vertex operator algebras are among the most important objects in the theory because they play crucial roles in theoretical physics, in particular, two-dimensional conformal field theory and string theory. The irreducible and unitary highest weight modules of the Virasoro algebra are of significant interest because they give rise to physically feasible states. The main goal of this project was to better understand the modular representations of the Virasoro algebra, where “modular” refers to objects considered over fields of prime characteristics. Virasoro vertex operator algebras over the field of complex numbers have been extensively studied while those over fields of prime characteristic are much more elusive. This project focused on determining the conditions on the prime characteristics for which certain classical results (i.e. over the field of complex numbers) remain true.

During this EAPSI project, the PI worked closely with her host advisor whom she had met during her 2016 EAPSI Fellowship. In addition, she attended a three-day seminar led by another Japanese mathematician who is an expert in Virasoro algebras. These opportunities allowed for strengthened communication with the Japanese mathematical community and laid the foundation for future collaboration.
